Again thank you and keep up the great work.

snippet.textDisplay: Nice video, a few issues, touching objects with "Unclean" hands (e.g. sink handle) , no gloves, etc.  I made up a solution of water, bleach ( 2 tbs per gallon), and a little liquid soap (5-10 drops per gallon), the soap (a surfactant)  breaks the surface tension of the fluid to lift the virus and get into cracks, similar to that used for the Ebola virus.  Bleach and soap go a long way if you use such a solution, but: It is important to lets this solution soak into the material.  15 minutes on a surface should kill the virus at room temperature.  I do 30 minutes.  Heat is the viruses enemy.  Cold is its friend.  They freeze virus samples to store them for years.  So, freezing is bad.  I spray (spray bottle) everything with this cleaning solution.  Bags, packages, all items including fresh fruits and vegetables.  Spray each item, roll it over and spray the bottom.  Leave everything for 30 minutes to soak.  Timer on the stove.  I have a towel soaked in the solution that I use the clean the gloves, it is sitting in a pan of the solution for tools (knife, scissors, etc).  I even spray some on the floor to walk on to help with the shoes.  I then open the packages and toss the outside surfaces for disposal outside.  I move other items to a clean area for further processing (e.g. rinsing the fresh items with water to remove the bleach / soap solution) and storage in the kitchen.  I do similar with the mail, out go the ads and junk mail for recycling, open packages that may contain items (pills, food, etc)  that can't take heat or microwave.  Then put the mail in an oven at around 180 for 30 minutes or with a glass of water in the microwave for 2 minutes.  Heat in an  oven at 160 - 200 F for 15 minutes should kill the virus, but I do 30 minutes ( I used an oven thermometer to check the temperature of the oven before doing anything), microwave is said to kill virus, i would think 2 minutes with a glass of water should do the trick.  The glass of water is to absorb the extra microwaves.  I have everything delivered (nice option if you can) and stay away from the delivery person.  WASH HANDS frequently for 20 seconds with soap.  Anal I know, but!   Thoughts?
snippet.textOriginal: Nice video, a few issues, touching objects with "Unclean" hands (e.g. sink handle) , no gloves, etc.  I made up a solution of water, bleach ( 2 tbs per gallon), and a little liquid soap (5-10 drops per gallon), the soap (a surfactant)  breaks the surface tension of the fluid to lift the virus and get into cracks, similar to that used for the Ebola virus.  Bleach and soap go a long way if you use such a solution, but: It is important to lets this solution soak into the material.  15 minutes on a surface should kill the virus at room temperature.  I do 30 minutes.  Heat is the viruses enemy.  Cold is its friend.  They freeze virus samples to store them for years.  So, freezing is bad.  I spray (spray bottle) everything with this cleaning solution.  Bags, packages, all items including fresh fruits and vegetables.  Spray each item, roll it over and spray the bottom.  Leave everything for 30 minutes to soak.  Timer on the stove.  I have a towel soaked in the solution that I use the clean the gloves, it is sitting in a pan of the solution for tools (knife, scissors, etc).  I even spray some on the floor to walk on to help with the shoes.  I then open the packages and toss the outside surfaces for disposal outside.  I move other items to a clean area for further processing (e.g. rinsing the fresh items with water to remove the bleach / soap solution) and storage in the kitchen.  I do similar with the mail, out go the ads and junk mail for recycling, open packages that may contain items (pills, food, etc)  that can't take heat or microwave.  Then put the mail in an oven at around 180 for 30 minutes or with a glass of water in the microwave for 2 minutes.  Heat in an  oven at 160 - 200 F for 15 minutes should kill the virus, but I do 30 minutes ( I used an oven thermometer to check the temperature of the oven before doing anything), microwave is said to kill virus, i would think 2 minutes with a glass of water should do the trick.  The glass of water is to absorb the extra microwaves.  I have everything delivered (nice option if you can) and stay away from the delivery person.  WASH HANDS frequently for 20 seconds with soap.  Anal I know, but!   Thoughts?

snippet.textDisplay:
I have never head of anyone recommending washing fruit with soap?! I was about to share until I saw this quack wack "doctor" washing fruit with soap!?

https://www.fda.gov/consumers/consumer-updates/7-tips-cleaning-fruits-vegetables

FDA Recommendation for washing fruit:
-Wash your hands for 20 seconds with warm water and soap before and after preparing fresh produce.
-If damage or bruising occurs before eating or handling, cut away the damaged or bruised areas before preparing or eating.
-Rinse produce BEFORE you peel it, so dirt and bacteria aren’t transferred from the knife onto the fruit or vegetable.
-Gently rub produce while holding under plain running water. There’s no need to use soap or a produce wash.
-Use a clean vegetable brush to scrub firm produce, such as melons and cucumbers.
-Dry produce with a clean cloth or paper towel to further reduce bacteria that may be present.
-Remove the outermost leaves of a head of lettuce or cabbage.
snippet.textOriginal:
I have never head of anyone recommending washing fruit with soap?! I was about to share until I saw this quack wack "doctor" washing fruit with soap!? 

https://www.fda.gov/consumers/consumer-updates/7-tips-cleaning-fruits-vegetables

FDA Recommendation for washing fruit: 
-Wash your hands for 20 seconds with warm water and soap before and after preparing fresh produce.
-If damage or bruising occurs before eating or handling, cut away the damaged or bruised areas before preparing or eating.
-Rinse produce BEFORE you peel it, so dirt and bacteria aren’t transferred from the knife onto the fruit or vegetable.
-Gently rub produce while holding under plain running water. There’s no need to use soap or a produce wash.
-Use a clean vegetable brush to scrub firm produce, such as melons and cucumbers.
-Dry produce with a clean cloth or paper towel to further reduce bacteria that may be present.
-Remove the outermost leaves of a head of lettuce or cabbage.

snippet.textDisplay:
Thank you. This is great!
However, I noticed when you opened the box of cereal (unsanitized), you used the same hands to touch the inside of the cereal bag. I guess like everything else, take the time to wipe it down then take stuff out just to be on the safe side. I spray all my groceries with rubbing alcohol and the bag/handle then clean and wash all groceries when I get home. Only worry is handling the meat because we don't cook it right away but instead put in the freezer :(

snippet.textDisplay: i know this video has been shared around - but it's RIDICULOUS.  If you are going to follow everything - i hope your pantry, fridge, and kitchen is completely emptied and wiped down to avoid "cross contamination" of historical items.  And the wrappers?  Just unwrap, then wash your hands before you handle your raw food, wash your hands before you eat (after you've poured some milk into your cup or bowel)...just wash your hands after you've handled anything from outside...and then never put anything from outside on your counter whatsoever.  This video is ridiculous.
snippet.textOriginal: i know this video has been shared around - but it's RIDICULOUS.  If you are going to follow everything - i hope your pantry, fridge, and kitchen is completely emptied and wiped down to avoid "cross contamination" of historical items.  And the wrappers?  Just unwrap, then wash your hands before you handle your raw food, wash your hands before you eat (after you've poured some milk into your cup or bowel)...just wash your hands after you've handled anything from outside...and then never put anything from outside on your counter whatsoever.  This video is ridiculous.

snippet.textDisplay: 25 years in the hazmat response/cleanup business. Excellent demonstration of contamination avoidance. I have been doing this since the virus started. snippet.textDisplay: I am a retired RN. Thanks to Dr. VanWingen for his generosity in producing this video. However, in the video I noticed two things I would not do.  First, I would not pick up a grocery bag from the floor and put it on a clean surface.  Also, I would not have put the medicine bottle on the clean surface without first wiping the bottom of the bottle.  These two errors effectively contaminate the clean surface.  In nursing we always considered the floor to be the most contaminated surface.   Hope this helps.
snippet.textOriginal: I am a retired RN. Thanks to Dr. VanWingen for his generosity in producing this video. However, in the video I noticed two things I would not do.  First, I would not pick up a grocery bag from the floor and put it on a clean surface.  Also, I would not have put the medicine bottle on the clean surface without first wiping the bottom of the bottle.  These two errors effectively contaminate the clean surface.  In nursing we always considered the floor to be the most contaminated surface.   Hope this helps.

snippet.textDisplay: Hello Jeffrey. I have a question, since there is a shortage of alcohol, I have been using hydrogen peroxide to wipe all the things I bought and brought from the outside especially grocery items. Is hydrogen peroxide good for disinfecting Covid-19? And if so, what is the recommended solution or preparation? I see bottles of 10 and 20 volumes. Which is better? Thank you.
snippet.textOriginal: Hello Jeffrey. I have a question, since there is a shortage of alcohol, I have been using hydrogen peroxide to wipe all the things I bought and brought from the outside especially grocery items. snippet.textDisplay:
My daughter's a certified ER registered nurse (or as you know...a CERN). However, she was offered, and accepted, a job in PACU. Now that non-emergent surgeries are cancelled, they've reassigned most of their staff. That's right...her taking the effort to get her CERN classification, she's now one of the frontline staff taking temps of persons wanting to walk into the ER. (Emergencies go in a different door as you know.) My son-in-law (her husband) recently stepped down from a LONG career as a Paramedic but is staying available on a prn basis.

My point? My point is to say thank you. To you, your colleagues and any medical professionals.
You. Are. Angels. ❤
snippet.textOriginal:

(Emergencies go in a different door as you know.) My son-in-law (her husband) recently stepped down from a LONG career as a Paramedic but is staying available on a prn basis. 

My point? My point is to say thank you. To you, your colleagues and any medical professionals. 
You. Are. Angels. ❤

snippet.textDisplay: So wow, while it's basically good advice, doc you must have been half awake when you were taught clean/sterile  vs. dirty/contaminated and how you keep the 2 seperate. For example - you cleaned with a disinfectanct saturated towel but then instead of throwing that now contaminated/dirty towel away, you sadly used it over and over and over again - occasionally to clean your hands, to clean the bag of vegies, to clean the plastic/cardboard box. You've just contaminated it all over again. That towel/rag needed to be thrown away!! Not reused again and again. When you held onto the cereal box, you ran your hands over it to demonstrated that the surfaces of it was dirty - then without cleaning your hand, you pulled out the plastic bag of cereal - thus contaminating the bag that you said was clean - well it was clean until you made it dirty with your hand. The blue cloth bag you put on the "clean" side of the counter, you just made it dirty by taking the bag that was on the floor and setting it onto the top of the counter. Ick! Then you wipe your hands with the rag that is still there, after having it go from clean to dirty. Sorry for the criticisms - but I'm a nurse, and your clean/dirty techniques were pathetic!
snippet.textOriginal: So wow, while it's basically good advice, doc you must have been half awake when you were taught clean/sterile  vs. dirty/contaminated and how you keep the 2 seperate. For example - you cleaned with a disinfectanct saturated towel but then instead of throwing that now contaminated/dirty towel away, you sadly used it over and over and over again - occasionally to clean your hands, to clean the bag of vegies, to clean the plastic/cardboard box. You've just contaminated it all over again. That towel/rag needed to be thrown away!! Not reused again and again. When you held onto the cereal box, you ran your hands over it to demonstrated that the surfaces of it was dirty - then without cleaning your hand, you pulled out the plastic bag of cereal - thus contaminating the bag that you said was clean - well it was clean until you made it dirty with your hand. The blue cloth bag you put on the "clean" side of the counter, you just made it dirty by taking the bag that was on the floor and setting it onto the top of the counter. Ick! Then you wipe your hands with the rag that is still there, after having it go from clean to dirty. Sorry for the criticisms - but I'm a nurse, and your clean/dirty techniques were pathetic!

snippet.textDisplay: Rather than breathe toxic sanitizers or get them on your skin leave the cardboard box somewhere for 24 hours. Don't touch the chips plastic bag until the suggested number of days has passed. In his wiping those bags he missed maybe a quarter of the surface (don't trust this guy to paint your room). Most virus transmission is through the air so when you went shopping you probably already breathed it in. Takeout food has a history of being tainted with coughs, sneezes, and outright food poisoning so avoid it and learn how to cook using basic ingredients.

snippet.textDisplay: I’ve passed on your very informative video to my cherished family members and friends. As a retired Paramedic, I can fully appreciate your sterile techniques. One more thing I would suggest, is to shower and change your clothes as contaminants can be on your clothing. Wash those clothes separate from your family’s laundry.

snippet.textDisplay:
If those bags are contaminated then they would send contaminants away from them, when moved around, into the air you breathe.

If coronavirus is airborne, it can travel into the cereal box, so the inside bag should be treated as contaminated as well. Especially if that box was contaminated itself, or near something contaminated.

When dumping bread into the clean container, you would dump contaminates from the outside of the bag into the clean container with the bread. I might pull the bread out carefully and not hover any contaminated things over clean things, bc of gravity.

The best thing to do is to leave everything outside for a few days. Rather than bringing unknown amounts of contaminants inside.
snippet.textOriginal:
If those bags are contaminated then they would send contaminants away from them, when moved around, into the air you breathe.

If coronavirus is airborne, it can travel into the cereal box, so the inside bag should be treated as contaminated as well. Especially if that box was contaminated itself, or near something contaminated. 

When dumping bread into the clean container, you would dump contaminates from the outside of the bag into the clean container with the bread. I might pull the bread out carefully and not hover any contaminated things over clean things, bc of gravity.

The best thing to do is to leave everything outside for a few days. Rather than bringing unknown amounts of contaminants inside.
